Project Description  The Project is a key environmental improvement and management 
initiative of the Hefei municipal government (HMG) to meet national 
environmental guidelines and ensure Hefei’s sustainable growth. 
The Project will bring tangible benefits to the environment of Hefei, 
the capital of Anhui province, by (i) enhancing the quality of its 
water  resources,  (ii)  strengthening  the  wastewater  treatment 
facilities  and  sewer  networks,  (iii)  reducing  the  incidence  and 
damage  of  flooding  in  three  rivers  and  Chao  Lake,  and  (iv) 
improving the urban air quality and reducing road accidents and 
vehicular emissions through a more efficient city road network and 
integrated  transport  management  operations  in  a  model 
development  zone.  The  Project  also  will  provide  institutional 
capacity-building measures in urban environmental management 
and  policy  reforms  to  ensure  sustainability  of  the  Project  and 
related facilities.  
 
The  Project  has  three  components:  (i)  wastewater  and  waste 
management, (ii) river rehabilitation and flood control improvement, 
and (iii) improved road infrastructure and traffic management in the 
Xinzhan zone. The Project also provides for institutional capacity 
building  for  project  management  and  operation.  The  Project 
supports the Government’s 11th Five-Year Program (2006–2010) 
to improve the living conditions and health in the cities of the PRC, 
and  to  promote  their  sustainable  economic  development.  It  is 
classified as a targeted intervention because it will contribute to 
achieving Millennium Development Goal 7, Target 10, which calls 
for halving the proportion of people without access to safe drinking 
water and basic sanitation. The Project is consistent with ADB’s 
water policy and Urban Sector Strategy. 
   
Rationale  Improving the urban environment in Hefei is crucial to achieving 
and  sustaining  HMG’s  medium-  to  long-term  development

ii   
objectives.  HMG  has  included  a  multisector  environmental 
protection program in the city’s 11th Five-Year Program. It also has 
identified a list of priority projects for ADB financing, including the 
proposed  Project,  which  will  improve  wastewater  management, 
flood control, and traffic management in Hefei.  
 
Water pollution and flooding are major environmental hazards in 
Hefei. The Nanfei River cuts through the heart of the city, flowing 
from west to east before turning south to drain into Chao Lake, one 
of the five major freshwater lakes in the PRC. Three tributaries of 
the Nanfei River, which flow through the northern sections of the 
city, are heavily polluted with sewage and wastewater dumped into 
the tributaries instead of being collected and sent to a wastewater 
treatment  plant  (WWTP).  The  WWTPs  in  Hefei  lack  sufficient 
capacity to handle all of the city’s wastewater, and the sewage 
network is also inadequate. The Nanfei River and its tributaries, as 
well  as  the  northern  end  of  Chao  Lake  within  the  Hefei 
municipality, are prone to flooding, which affects the immediate 
urban area. In addition, the filled and closed solid waste landfill 
nearby seeps wastewater directly into the river and indirectly into 
the groundwater. Adequate protection of this landfill and disposal 
of seeping wastewater in a WWTP are urgently required.  
 
Major traffic jams and flow problems in the city worsen air pollution 
and traffic accidents. To improve traffic flow and reduce vehicular 
emissions, HMG plans to construct expressways and flyovers, and 
upgrade traffic signal networks, using its own resources. It has 
requested assistance from ADB to upgrade the road network and 
install a better traffic surveillance system and traffic management 
scheme as a pilot component of the proposed Project in Xinzhan, a 
high-growth industrial and residential zone. This area is adjacent to 
the  main  stations  that  connect  Hefei  with  the  national  railway 
networks. The area will form a hub for transport services, including 
buses,  logistic  centers,  and  freight  vehicle  operations.  A 
sustainable road safety strategy and vehicle emissions control plan 
will  be  implemented  in  the  area,  while  the  new  roads  will  be 
provided with full sewerage and environmental protection systems. 
Xinzhan has been developed to complement increasing demand 
for urbanization in Hefei. Industrial and manufacturing growth in 
this area also would help reduce poverty in the city through the 
provision of job opportunities. 
   
Impact and Outcome  Impact: The Project aims to improve the urban environment, public 
health, and quality of life in Hefei by reducing the incidence of 
waterborne  and  airborne  diseases,  road  accidents,  and  vehicle 
emissions;  and  by  increasing  employment,  and  investment  and 
business opportunities.  
 
Outcome:  The  Project  seeks  to  improve  public  wastewater 
management, flood control, and transport services in Hefei.

Project Benefits and  The Project will benefit directly about 2.61 million people living in 
Beneficiaries  the project area, of which about 5.2% are poor (measured by the 
weighted average local urban poverty line of CNY2,760 per year or 
CNY230 ($29.11) per month, which is close to the $1 per day 
poverty line). All the residents of Hefei will benefit indirectly. The 
living environment will improve as a result of (i) reduced pollution of 
Hefei’s surface water, with water quality improving to at least class 
V by 2012 with longer-term potential to be upgraded to class IV 
and class III; (ii) protection from flooding and elimination of hazards 
due  to  poor  drainage;  (iii)  10%  reduction  in  the  incidence  of 
waterborne  and  airborne  diseases  from  2005  levels,  with  a 
corresponding decline in the number of sick days and expenses for 
medical treatment; and (iv) increased traffic flow, better energy 
efficiency, and reduced waiting times as a result of an improved 
road network and an innovative traffic management system, which 
will  reduce  traffic  accidents,  enhance  productivity,  and  lower 
vehicular emissions.

v
The Project will provide 2,830 full-time jobs during construction, of 
which  about  60%  will  be  for  the  poor  and  women.  Project 
operations will create 1,080 permanent full-time jobs directly and 
another  1,730  jobs  through  multiplier  effects,  generating 
approximately  CNY45  million  in  wages  per  year.  Public  health 
benefits  will  accrue  through  a  reduction  in  the  incidence  of 
waterborne  and  airborne  diseases,  savings  on  treatment  costs, 
and  improved  workforce  productivity.  The  Project  is  technically 
sound,  affordable  to  the  beneficiaries,  and  financially  and 
economically viable and sustainable. Through policy dialogue, the 
Project will continue to support HMG in tariff reform to ensure cost 
recovery, and in strengthening the capacities of wastewater utilities 
to become more attractive for eventual private sector participation. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  Project  does  not  have  any  unusual  technical  risks. 
Conventional engineering designs with proven records of reliable 
performance will be adopted for wastewater management, landfill 
closure, flood control, road construction, and traffic management 
and  associated  landscaping.  During  project  implementation,  the 
consultants  will  support  the  PMO  and  IAs  to  ensure  delivered 
equipment and works comply with the design requirements and 
quality standards.  
 
The  following  risks  could  affect  timely  implementation  and 
economic viability, and reduce the available benefits of the Project: 
(i) amendments and changes to the Hefei master plans, particularly 
for the Xinzhan zone, which could delay the Project; (ii) lack of 
proper  operation  and  maintenance  of  project  facilities;  (iii) 
ineffective organizational structures and inadequate capacity of the 
IAs, which could result in inefficient project development and delay 
implementation; (iv) delay in the provision of counterpart funding; 
(v)  failure  of  HMG  to  increase  wastewater  tariffs  to  meet  cost 
recovery  targets;  and  (vi)  unforeseen  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement  issues,  which  could  constrain  the  efficient 
implementation of the project works and restoration of livelihoods 
of affected persons. 
 
Risk (i) will be mitigated by synchronizing the project design and 
implementation  schedules  with  other  projects  planned  in  Hefei. 
HMG also has provided specific assurances that are covenanted in 
the Loan Agreement. Risks (ii) and (iii) will be mitigated through 
provision of institutional capacity building for the IAs with support of 
loan  consultants.  Risks  (iv)  and  (v)  will  be  mitigated  through 
covenanted assurances from HMG on the provision of counterpart 
funding, and regular tariff reviews and increases. Risk (vi) will be 
mitigated by strengthening the internal monitoring and supervision 
by PMO and the IAs, and by engaging a qualified external agency 
to monitor and evaluate resettlement.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the People's Republic of China (PRC) for the Anhui Hefei Urban Environment Improvement Project 
(the Project). 
 
2.  The Government asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help improve the urban 
environment  in  Hefei  city,  the  capital  of  Anhui  province,  by  strengthening  its  wastewater 
management, enhancing the quality of its water resources by reducing pollution and damage from 
flooding, and improving urban air quality and traffic management. The Project is consistent with 
ADB’s Medium-Term Strategy (2006–2008), water policy, and Urban Sector Strategy.1 It will help 
the PRC achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDG) for environmental sustainability and 
increased access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation. This report is based on the results of 
the  Loan  Appraisal  Mission,  as  well  as  discussions  with  the  central  and  local  governments, 
relevant agencies, and community organizations. The design and monitoring framework of the 
Project is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.  Since the PRC initiated economic reforms in 1978, rapid urbanization has accompanied 
significant economic progress.  The urban population has nearly tripled from about 190 million in 
1980 to more than 560 million in 2005, and now accounts for more than 43% of the national 
population. The Government’s Agenda for Economic Reform and Social Development aims to 
accelerate urbanization and the development of towns and cities, particularly in metropolitan areas.  
Consequently, the urban population is expected to reach 47% of the total population by 2010, 
thereby  increasing  the  demand  for  urban  services.2   The  increasing    urban    population, 
industrialization,  and  economic  development  are  straining  the  overloaded  infrastructure,  and 
contributing to widespread pollution and environmental threats in PRC’s cities. Without significant 
investment, the urban environment will degrade, economic development will be encumbered, and 
people’s quality of life will deteriorate. 
 
4.  Municipal wastewater is a major contributor to the pollution of PRC rivers and lakes. In 
2005, only about 48.4% of urban wastewater was treated, with the remainder discharged raw and 
untreated into the rivers and lakes. In the seven major river basins,3 41.8% of the water does not 
meet PRC’s class III water quality standard and is unacceptable as a source of municipal water 
supply.4 To reduce pollution in the country’s lakes and rivers, a number of actions are needed, 
including (i) strengthening laws and regulations, (ii) adopting a holistic approach to water resources 
management in river basins, (iii) reducing nonpoint sources of pollution, (iv) continuing investment 
in the construction of wastewater treatment plants (WWTP), and (v) continuing institutional and 
financial management reforms to facilitate more balanced economic growth and environmental 
sustainability.  
 
5.  In  PRC’s  11th  Five-Year  Program  (FYP)  covering  2006–2010,  the  Government  has 
prioritized addressing environmental issues, including water and air pollution, through policy reform,

increased investment, and improved urban infrastructure management. Recognizing that adequate 
environmental protection and pollution controls are essential for sustainable economic growth, the 
Government has made environmental protection a national priority in its development strategy. In 
addition to environmental protection laws and implementing regulations that emphasize prevention, 
the ”polluter pays” principle, and decentralized environmental management, the Government has 
undertaken  many  programs,  including  several  for  wastewater  management.5 Industries  were 
ordered to treat wastewater to national discharge standards by the end of 2000. Municipalities 
have been required under successive FYPs to address wastewater collection, treatment, and 
disposal. Pollution control plans have been developed and implementation started for the key river 
basins. Government policies require urban environmental pollution and ecological damage to be 
controlled by 2010. Under recent state guidelines, major cities, including provincial capitals, are 
expected to have wastewater treatment rates of at least 80% by that year.6  Furthermore, the 
Government's economic and enterprise reform programs require that all wastewater projects be 
financially  sustainable  and  capable  of  cost  recovery.  The  State  Environmental  Protection 
Administration requires all new WWTPs to provide at least secondary wastewater treatment. The 
mandated treatment level depends on the quality of the receiving water.  
 
6.  Improving road infrastructure, traffic management, and vehicular emission controls are key 
areas  of  the  Government’s  policy  to  ensure  sustainable  development,  while  protecting  the 
environment.  By  the  end  of  2005,  more  than  1.9  million  kilometers  (km)  of  roads  had  been 
constructed in the PRC with a major focus on expressways.7 Vehicle ownership also has been 
increasing rapidly, doubling in the past 10 years to almost 21 vehicles per 1,000 people. If trends 
continue, vehicle ownership will quadruple from 2005 levels by 2020. Such rapid growth in vehicle 
ownership necessitates adequate transport planning, and improved road and traffic management. 
Although no specific urban road development plans exist at the state level, individual cities and 
municipalities must submit their master plans for urban development, including road infrastructure, 
to the State Council for approval. Local governments also are required to include road safety, traffic 
management, and vehicular emission control schemes in their development plans.  
 
7.  Hefei municipality, capital of Anhui province, is also the commercial and industrial center. 
With a population of about 4.5 million, the municipality includes four urban districts and three 
counties spread over 7,029 square kilometers.8 The topography of the area is dominated by rivers, 
streams, and lakes. The Nanfei River, a tributary of the Yangtze River and Chao Lake system, 
flows southeast through Hefei to Chao Lake, one of the five major freshwater lakes in PRC. 
Although Hefei is hilly, the built-up areas are generally flat with elevations of 12–15 meters above 
sea level. Although this is above normal flood height, some low-lying areas along the Nanfei River 
and its tributaries are prone to flooding. Since 1949, the city has experienced 18 floods, four of 
which were disastrous.

manufacturing  industries  and  high-tech  research  centers,  with  associated  residential

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
9.  Project  Background.  The  management  of  wastewater,  water  resources,  and  traffic 
management is the key to improving the urban environment by (i) reducing water pollution; (ii) 
decreasing the occurrence of floods; (iii) reducing air pollution; (iv) promoting sustainable economic 
development; and (v) improving the living conditions and public health of urban residents, including 
the poor. In the past, the Government was the sole provider of these urban services, which were 
funded by tax revenues. Consumers paid minimal or no charges. Over the past decade, the 
Government has shifted towards a more market-orientated approach, enterprise provision in the 
delivery of infrastructure services, and a more integrated approach to urban development and 
environmental management. Despite significant progress, more investment and improvement is 
needed in wastewater, flood control, and traffic management systems. Socioeconomic surveys 
have shown that the public is becoming increasingly concerned about and more attuned to the 
impact of wastewater, flooding, and air pollution. Further, the public is increasingly willing to pay for 
the necessary treatment and environmental improvement. While wastewater companies have been 
established in many cities, many are not financially or managerially independent. Tariffs generally 
have not been increased enough to achieve full cost recovery. Therefore, corporate governance 
needs  to  be  improved  and  key  personnel  trained,  and  the  enterprises  must  become  more 
commercially orientated and stronger. 
 
10.  Since 2000, the economy of Hefei has grown at an annual average rate of 13.5%. The 
combination of rapid economic growth, industrialization, and urbanization have led to major urban 
environmental issues in Hefei, including (i) acute shortages of wastewater facilities and sewer 
pipelines; (ii) uncontrolled leaks and pollution from a closed landfill site; (iii) poor flood control 
design and planning, and inadequate flood protection measures; and (iv) poor traffic management 
and road quality.9 These problems, in turn, have caused poor water quality in the Nanfei River and 
its tributaries, as well as in Chao Lake. Further, they have increased flooding and air pollution, 
which have created health hazards, damaged assets (industries and roads), and contributed to a 
general deterioration in the quality of life for residents of Hefei city. At the same time, Hefei is 
facing the problems of sustaining employment and income-earning opportunities, and providing 
adequate health and education services to the growing population. Aware of the environmental 
degradation, HMG has embarked on a multisector environmental protection program that will meet 
national environmental guidelines and ensure Hefei's sustainable growth.10  HMG also needs 
assistance to achieve the MDG for environmental sustainability (Goal 7), which aims to halve the 
proportion of people without sustainable access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation by 2015 
(Target 10).

11.  Project Rationale. Improving the urban environment by reducing water and air pollution, 
and strengthening environmental protection and management in Hefei, is crucial to achieving and 
sustaining the municipality’s medium-term development objectives. To this end, HMG has identified 
a list of priority environment-related investment activities, including the proposed Project, which 
supports the PRC’s and Hefei’s urban development and environmental management objectives. 
The Project is also consistent with ADB’s Water Policy and the recently adopted Water Financing 
Program,  which  seek  to  improve  urban  water  investments  by  providing  investments  in  water 
supply, sanitation and wastewater management, and environmental improvement.11 
 
12.  Water pollution and flooding are major environmental hazards in Hefei. The Nanfei River 
cuts through the heart of the city, flowing from west to east before turning south to drain into Chao 
Lake. Three tributaries of the Nanfei River, which flow through the northern sections of the city, are 
heavily polluted with sewage and wastewater discharged into the rivers instead of being collected 
and treated at WWTPs. The WWTPs lack sufficient capacity to handle all of the city’s wastewater, 
and the sewage network is also inadequate. These tributaries are also prone to flooding (every 3–5 
years), although the Nanfei River floods much less frequently (reportedly every 20–50 years) 
because of flood protection infrastructure. The northern end of Chao Lake is prone to flooding, 
which affects the immediate urban area and backs up the Nanfei River and its tributaries. In 
addition, a filled and closed solid waste landfill nearby is seeping waste directly into the Nanfei 
River and indirectly into the groundwater. Adequate protection of this closed landfill and disposal of 
seepage in a WWTP are urgently required. Hence, the Project will bring significant environmental 
benefits to Hefei by improving water pollution and flood management. 
 
13.  Major traffic jams and flow problems in Hefei worsen air pollution and increase traffic 
accidents.  To  improve  traffic  flow  and  reduce  vehicular  emissions,  HMG  plans  to  construct 
expressways, flyovers, and improved traffic signal systems using its own resources. HMG has 
requested assistance from ADB to upgrade the road network and install a pilot traffic management 
system in Xinzhan, a planned high-growth industrial and residential zone. This area is adjacent to 
stations on the railway network that connect Hefei with key commodities transfer points, which 
support the movement of goods and people, enhance transport services for low-income groups, 
and create an integrated and holistic transport system. Industrial and manufacturing growth in the 
Xinzhan Zone would help reduce poverty in the city through the provision of job opportunities. The 
planned ADB assistance in this zone is for the development of a pilot integrated road infrastructure 
and innovative traffic management system that could be replicated later throughout Hefei and 
elsewhere. HMG will provide the remaining infrastructure to the Xinzhan Zone, including electricity, 
water supply, and sewer and gas transmission lines.

16.  Floods in rapidly growing cities damage urban property and have high recovery costs. The 
flood control system in the PRC emphasizes the use of structural measures to reduce flood

flood-prone  areas.  To  mitigate  flood  risks,  nonstructural  approaches  increasingly  are  used,

17.  Sustainable transport planning is central to implementing the Hefei Urban Master Plan. The

and degrades the quality of life of urban residents. The lack of roads and traffic congestion 
increasingly is making Hefei’s suburban and new industrial areas difficult to access, and less 
attractive  to  employers  and  residents.  The  limited  road  space  and  inefficient  use  of  traffic 
management are creating safety concerns for drivers, pedestrians, and non-motorized transport 
users.12 A well-planned urban road network, combined with an efficient traffic management system 
that includes vehicular emission controls, is necessary to ensure the sustainable development of 
Hefei. It will reduce time lost due to traffic congestion, improve efficiency of energy consumption by

enforcement, transport services, maintenance plan, and interagency coordination mechanism. This 
scheme is expected to be replicated in other parts of Hefei and other cities.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
23.  The impact of the Project is to improve the urban environment, public health, and quality of 
life  in  Hefei  by  reducing  waterborne  and  airborne  diseases,  road  accidents,  and  vehicular 
emissions; and increasing employment, investment, and business opportunities. The outcome of 
the Project will be improved public wastewater management, flood control, and transport services 
in Hefei by  
 
(i)  increasing the wastewater treatment rate from 50% to 80% by 2012;  
(ii)  upgrading the water quality from much worse than class V to at least class V in 
Banqiao, Ershibu, and Sili rivers by 2012, with longer-term potential for upgrading to 
between class IV and class V by 2015 and eventually to class III;  
(iii)  reducing the probability of floods in the Banqiao, Ershibu, and Sili rivers from an 
average of every 3–5 years to 50–100 years by 2011–2012;  
(iv)  reducing the probability of floods in Chao Lake from an average of every 10–20 
years  to  at  least  every  20  years,  and  reducing  erosion  of  the  lake  bank  and 
improving the ecological environment of the lake by 2012; and  
(v)  creating a sustainable road transport system that is safe, economically viable, and 
environmentally  friendly  in  the  Xinzhan  Zone  by  2012,  resulting  in  increased 
industrial development, more jobs, and better health and safety.  
 
B.  Outputs 
24.  The Project has three components and related capacity building, broken down into 10 
subcomponents (outputs) and 30 activities, which contribute to and fundamentally support Hefei’s 
11th FYP and beyond. The subcomponents include improved wastewater management through 
the construction of WWTPs and expansion of the sewer network; environmental improvement, and 
effective protection of a closed landfill; river rehabilitation and flood control works; improved road 
infrastructure  and  traffic  management  in  the  Xinzhan  Zone,  with  an  innovative  pilot  traffic 
management  and  control  system;  and  institutional  capacity  building  for  effective  and  efficient 
project  implementation  and  management.  Supplementary  Appendixes  B,  C,  and  D  provide 
technical details of the physical components. 
 
25.  Wastewater  and  waste  management  of  Hefei  city  has  four  subcomponents.  The  first 
subcomponent is the construction of the Shiwuli River WWTP with a capacity of 50,000 cubic

C.  Special Features 
29.  The Project is ADB’s first multisector urban environment improvement project in the PRC 
that aims to integrate urban development and environmental management to ensure long-term 
sustainable growth. It also will provide experience for future ADB-financed urban projects in the 
PRC.  The  Project  builds  on  and  advances  ADB’s  policy  dialogue  and  initiatives  with  the 
Government in several key areas, including (i) urban environment and wastewater management, 
(ii) cost recovery and tariff reform, (iii) corporate governance and enterprise reform, (iv) integrated 
urban infrastructure development and sustainable transport system, and (v) PSP.

30.  The Project has been designed to support HMG in creating an enabling environment for 
PSP through tariff reform and improved corporate governance. ADB’s experience in Hefei (para. 
19 and footnote 14) suggests that this is a successful approach to attracting PSP in the longer

predominantly from low-income groups; and (c) increase the economic benefits of 
the infrastructure investment; and  
(iii)  integration with other transport modes and logistics centers.20   
 
32.  Rehabilitation of the closed Qingxi Road Landfill site is an innovative scheme to support

the landfill will eliminate contamination to surface and groundwater, and reduce obnoxious odor to 
surrounding residents. As such, this initiative would have demonstration effect for other urban 
areas with improperly managed landfill sites. Consequently, these special features and initiatives

A.  Project Benefits and Impacts 
50.  The Project will benefit directly about 2.61 million people living in the project area, of whom

reduction  in  the  incidence  of  waterborne  and  airborne  diseases  from  2005  levels,  with  a

increased traffic flow and shorter waiting times due to an innovative traffic management system

vehicle emissions.

C.  Financial Analysis, Sustainability, and Affordability Aspects 
56.  The Project is considered financially viable and sustainable. A financial impact analysis of

others) was undertaken. A financial management assessment of the IAs also was conducted. 
These are discussed in Appendix 11. Details of the financial impact analysis are in Supplementary

57.  HWTAD,  which  is  funded  through  budget  allocations  from  the  HFB,  constructed  and 
operated the wastewater subcomponents. Wastewater costs are recovered from all water supply 
consumers through a wastewater tariff of CNY0.6 per m3 for domestic consumers and a weighted 
average of CNY0.69 per m3 for all consumers. The financial assessment of sustainability was 
undertaken for the entire wastewater operation, including HWTAD operations and capital finance 
from HFB. Financial activity was projected over a 30-year operating period based on anticipated 
costs, sales, and tariffs with and without the Project.  
 
58.  The analysis indicates that, if tariffs increase with inflation, wastewater operations will be 
profitable at the municipality level. Further, tariff revenues would be sufficient to cover counterpart 
funds during loan implementation and service the ADB loan. HMG is aware that the costs of 
WWTP operators might increase. In line with its commitment to tariff reform, HMG is planning a 
minimum increase of 50% in wastewater tariffs in 2007. HMG realizes that additional increases will 
be required by the time the new WWTPs are operational, and has indicated that a domestic tariff of 
CNY1.1 per m3 can be assumed for 2010 (nearly double the current CNY0.6 per m3). This would 
put the tariff just above the financial average incremental cost of CNY1.0 per m3. If the wastewater 
tariff is increased to CNY1.1 per m3 by 2010, each of the new WWTPs would achieve full cost 
recovery, which potentially could attract PSP.

63.  The economic analysis provides a rationale and justification for the Project based on policy,

rationale, the rationale for public intervention, the goals of the investment plan, the design of the

externalities (water and air pollution) and managing natural monopolies (wastewater treatment and 
urban road provision). The main goal of the investment plan is to meet targets for surface water

decrease flooding and provide significant amenities, many of which will be used by the poor. The 
road component includes traffic management to control congestion, accidents, and air pollution.

cost of capital), and the Project’s overall economic internal rate of return is 27%. A summary

F.  Projects Risks and Mitigation Measures 
66.  The Project does not have any unusual technical risks. Conventional engineering designs 
with proven records of reliable performance will be adopted for wastewater management, landfill 
closure, flood control, road construction and traffic management, and associated landscaping. 
During project implementation, the consultants will support the PMO and IAs to ensure delivered 
equipment and works comply with the design requirements and quality standards.  
 
67.  The following risks could affect timely implementation and economic viability, and reduce 
the available benefits of the Project: (i) amendments and changes to the Hefei master plans, 
particularly for the Xinzhan Zone, which could delay the Project; (ii) lack of proper O&M of project 
facilities; (iii) ineffective organizational structures and inadequate capacity of the IAs, which could 
result in inefficient project development and implementation delays; (iv) delays in the provision of 
counterpart funding; (v) failure of HMG to increase wastewater tariffs to meet cost recovery targets; 
and (vi) unforeseen land acquisition and resettlement issues, which could constrain the efficient 
implementation of the project works and restoration of livelihoods of the APs.

URBAN SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Before the economic reforms of the 1980s, the Government of the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) was the sole provider of urban services. Wastewater management practice was 
based on septic tanks, designated open drainage ditches, and no treatment. Urban services were 
funded through tax revenue, and consumers paid minimal or no charges. Road infrastructure also 
was poorly developed and vehicle ownership was very low 
 
2.  When economic reforms started in 1978, the urban population grew significantly from about 
160 million (17% of the population) in 1975 to 560 million (43% of the population) in 2005.  This 
trend is expected to increase to levels of 50% or more over the next 10 years. With this population 
growth came an increase in the number of cities—from 122 in 1949 to 661 in 2004. This rapid 
urbanization has increased the pressure on the environment, as well as the management and 
financing of public services. The urbanization of rural areas and the high rates of rural-to-urban 
migration have resulted in a large proportion of migrants living in inadequately serviced peri-urban 
areas.  This  increases  pressure  on  infrastructure  services,  including  urban  transport,  power, 
telecommunication, water supply, wastewater treatment, and solid waste management. 
 
3.  Hefei  municipality,  which  comprises  four  urban  districts  and  three  counties,  has  a 
population of 4.5 million. Like most cities in the PRC, Hefei has grown rapidly over the past 20 
years. The population is expected to increase to 6.3 million by 2010 and 8.0 million by 2020. The 
municipal gross domestic product is forecast to increase 13.5% per year on average during 2006–
2010. By 2010, the urbanization rate in Hefei will reach 60%. With the development of high-speed 
economy,  the  spread  of  urbanization,  and  increase  of  population,  the  city’s  environmental 
conditions  (including  wastewater  and  waste  management),  traffic  situation,  and  quality  of 
groundwater continue to deteriorate and need urgent attention. 
 
B.  Hefei Urban Plans 
 
4.  The Hefei 11th Five-Year Program (FYP) for 2006–2010 and the Hefei Urban Development 
Master Plan (in draft form) are the blueprints for the physical, economic, and social development of 
Hefei in the medium to long term. These plans are based on the population projections of 6.3 
million in 2010 and 8 million in 2020.  
 
5.  The urban master plan proposes a redevelopment of the old urban center into a new trade 
and finance center. New residential and industrial developments are under construction, and more 
are planned in all directions from the middle of the city to cater for Hefei’s prominent role as a 
modern science and technology center. Hefei also is becoming an increasingly important road and 
rail transport hub, which will take on more significance when the planned Jianghuai canal linking 
the Yangtze and the Huai river systems is constructed.   
 
6.  Economic growth in Hefei is planned simultaneously with expanded urbanization of land 
and population growth. In the 11th FYP, the urban area will increase by 33% from 2005 to 2010.  
Annual growth rates of 15.5% are forecast for 2006–2010, and a per capita gross domestic product 
of  $5,000  is  forecast  in  2010.  Such  growth  will  exert  substantial  pressure  on  the  urban 
infrastructure,  and  will  create  much  demand  for  improvement  and  expansion.  Wastewater 
treatment, sewer network replacement, flood control, and improved traffic management are urgent 
areas for upgrading and expansion. The Asian Development Bank-financed Project is essential to 
help the Hefei municipal government (HMG) realize its development goals.

C.  Water Sector 
 
7.  The Hefei piped water system takes water from the Dongpu and Dafangyin reservoirs, 
which receive good quality water from the upper reaches of the Nanfei River. Widespread pollution 
sources downstream of these reservoirs lowers river water quality to Class V—well below the 
Class III required for urban piped water supply. As a result, water can no longer be abstracted from 
the rivers or from Chao Lake, one of the five major freshwater lakes in the PRC. Chao Lake, which 
is part of the “left bank river system” of the lower reaches of the Yangtze River, has at least six 
rivers running into it. The lake has an artificially controlled level with a storage capacity of 4.8 billion 
cubic meters (m3). The development of cities and industrial plants around the lake, and increasing 
amounts of agricultural fertilizers and pesticides seeping into the lake, has severely polluted the 
water.  
 
8.  As urbanization increases, the Dongpu and the Dafangyin reservoirs to the north of the city 
also face serious pollution problems, with domestic and other sewage discharged freely. The 
Dongpu provides water to all four Hefei water treatment plants (WTP) (also referred to as water 
purification plants), and the Dafangyin will serve the planned WTP No. 6. A separate drainage and 
wastewater system is planned for this area, which will help to protect the reservoirs as water 
sources. 
 
9.  The Hefei Water Supply Group Co. Ltd (HWSC), wholly owned by HMG, supplies piped 
water in Hefei. The Hefei Water Supply Office administers the sector. The separate Hefei Water 
Affairs Bureau deals with all waters and water resources, including rivers, flood control, etc., 
although it is in charge of only the Chao Lake subcomponent of the Project. Piped water supply 
capacity of the four WTPs in Hefei is 875,000 m3/day. Raw water pumping stations abstract from 
the Dongpu Reservoir. A similar station on Chao Lake no longer is used due to water pollution. In 
addition, five local pressurization stations distribute the treated water. The majority of the pipes are 
nearly 40 years old, with some as old as 50 years. Water losses have increased from 7% in 2000 
to 12% in 2005 (on top of 2–3% production losses). Although this is low by international standards, 
the trend is causing concern since the old pipes are obviously deteriorating. Besides the Hefei City 
districts, HWSC also provides water to Shangpai town (50,000 m3/day in 2010) in Feixi county, and 
Modian township (20,000 m3/day in 2010) in the Yaohai Industrial Area. Plans also are being made 
to supply Shangdun town and Luyang and Shauangfeng industrial areas (50,000 m3/day in 2010). 
 
10.  In addition to HWSC, 25 self-providing water works in Hefei have been built by large-scale 
enterprises and scientific research institutes. Taken together, these add 20–25% to the water 
supply.  The  city  districts  also  might  have  small  private  wells,  as  in  the  counties.  The  Hefei 
Municipal Waster Supply Plan and its update state that Hefei groundwater is a scarce resource 
and extraction should be controlled. Although future use of groundwater might be necessary, 
consumers should be encouraged to use piped water. 
 
11.  Domestic water consumption recorded by HWSC, and using their own population served 
estimates, was some 165–170 liter per capita per day (lpcd) in 2005. This consumption drops to 
156 lpcd if the entire registered population is assumed to be served and to 121 lpcd if the total 
population is included. Even the latter is higher than the 112 lpcd recorded as a PRC urban median 
by  the  China  Water  Supply  Association  in  2004.  Industrial  demand  in  Hefei  has  declined  in 
absolute and percentage terms. In 1995, it was 68,000 m3, or 42% of total sales. In 2004, it was 
only 40,000 m3, or 20% of the total. The reason for the decline is the change in type of industry and 
the city’s efforts to promote efficient use of water.

12.  The Hefei Wastewater Treatment Administrative Department plans and controls wastewater 
in Hefei. Ownership is more complex, however. A Sino-German joint venture operates the largest

13.  The extension of the city into new areas will increase the need for a sewerage network, as 
well as treatment. The city has four full-scale WWTPs, with a combined capacity of 437,000 m3/ 
day. This is 50% of the city’s maximum water supply capacity of 875,000 m3/day, but about 70% of

expected  increase  in  wastewater  flows.  The  Project  will  finance  Wangtang  WWTP  II,  with  a

or 30,000–50,000 m3/day, is recycled. The 11th FYP proposes that this should increase to 260,000 
m3/day, a 20-fold increase, by 2010. To meet this expectation, tertiary treatment (water purification) 
is proposed for the Wantang WWTP II. 
 
14.  The sewer and wastewater network is 250 kilometers (km) long, with a capacity to handle 
437,000 m3/day. This is only a proportion of total requirements. By 2010, the Project will provide an

15.  Wastewater treatment produces significant amounts of sludge, which makes disposal an 
important part of operations. The rate of sludge production is approximately 0.5%–1.3% of the

16.  Sludge  contains  large  amounts  of  organic  matter,  comprising  nutrients  and  disease-
inducing  organisms  and/or  toxic  substances.  Consequently,  the  sludge  must  be  treated  and 
utilized, or disposed of carefully. If simply piled freely, secondary contamination would result, 
causing widespread surface and groundwater pollution with serious consequences for recipient

these options to select the most cost-effective solution. In the interim, surplus sludge that is not

3.  Flood Control 
 
18.  Although Hefei has been prone to flooding, much work has been done in the past 50 years

E.  Local Government Poverty-Reduction Policies 
7.  The primary program supporting registered poor families is a basic subsidy, called the 
minimum living guarantee, designed to maintain a minimum level of income. Registered families 
with incomes below the official poverty line receive help under this program. Subsidies are meant 
to cover all expenses, including the water bill. The size of this security payment makes up the 
difference between the poverty line and the actual income of the household. The official poverty 
line in Hefei is CNY230 per person per month. 
 
8.  Some cities in the People’s Republic of China offer other poverty-reduction programs in 
addition to the minimum living guarantee. In Hefei, registered households below the official poverty 
line receive the first 4 cubic meters (m3) of water consumed per month at no charge. The cost of 
this program to HWSC is offset by a subsidy from the government.1 
 
F.  Tariff Impacts on Poor Households 
9.  The Project might require wastewater tariffs to increase. Hefei municipal government plans 
to increase the wastewater tariff by 50% to CNY0.9 per m3 in 2007 and possibly to CNY1.1 per m3 
by 2010. The tariff increases will achieve full cost recovery, comply with state government policy on 
the wastewater tariff, and likely account for funding requirements that go beyond project financing 
needs. 
 
10.  Estimates were made of monthly household water use, the resulting household water and 
wastewater bill for low-income households, average household subsidy based on household size 
information from the Anhui statistical yearbook, and water demand assumptions (Table A12.5). 
The 50% tariff increase is used in this analysis as a base, though the effects of an 83% increase to 
CNY 1.1 per m3 also are shown. 
 
11.  Based on the analysis summarized in Table A12.5, households would appear to be able to 
afford the tariff increase, even if they are in the lowest income class receiving no water subsidy

income expended for the service is 3.9%, which is below the 5% benchmark assumed for water 
and wastewater together.   
 
G.  Mitigation of Tariff Impacts 
12.  Poor households have little scope for absorbing even small tariff increases, given their 
current allocation of expenditures. Low-income households experiencing the most extreme poverty 
are the most likely to be adversely affected by the tariff increase. Factors contributing to extreme 
poverty include elevated health care costs associated with poor health of a household member, 
and single-person households that preclude sharing common costs among several persons. Such 
households might require additional support if their water bill increases. The main policies used to 
support poor households facing increasing tariffs are lifeline tariffs, water bill discounts, and direct 
subsidies. As the lifeline tariff is a poorly targeted policy that benefits all households, not just those 
needing support, it is not recommended. The existing water bill discount is a much better poverty-
reduction measure, because it can be targeted properly at poor households. Consideration could 
be given to extending it to non-registered households.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The economic analysis covers the Project as a whole and the individual subcomponents.  
For the Project as a whole, the analysis covers (i) the overall economic rationale, (ii) the rationale 
for public intervention, (iii) the goals of the investment plan, (iv) the general design of the plan, and 
(v)  the  overall  economic  benefit  to  be  expected.  The  economic  analysis  also  evaluates  the 
individual subcomponents for least costs and economic internal rate of return (EIRR). Economic 
analysis was conducted in accordance with the Asian Development Bank’s Guidelines for the 
Economic Analysis of Projects and Economic Analysis Retrospective 2005: Strengthening ADB’s 
Aid Effectiveness. 
 
B.  Analysis of the Project 
1.  Rationale for the Project 
2.  The primary motivation for the investment plan is the increasing concern over the effects of 
economic growth on environmental quality in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Continuing 
urbanization has resulted in water and air pollution, and in the potential for increasing water 
shortages. Surface, groundwater, and air pollution pose risks for public health and the environment 
in general.  Pollution also is starting to constrain national and local development.  
 
3.  Hefei City urban population increased by a third during the last 5-year plan, and real per 
capita gross domestic product doubled in each of the last two plan periods. The same growth is 
forecast in the 11th Five-Year Program (2006–2010), and is also expected for the period starting 
2010. The urban part of the city lies along the Nanfei River. The Nanfei runs into Chao Lake, which 
is a source for the Yangtze River. The waters of the Nanfei and Chao Lake are polluted and 
classified as suitable only for agriculture and landscaping. A potential major urban recreational and 
environmental benefit is all but unused. The Project contains subcomponents that will affect water 
pollution directly by cleaning rivers and treating wastewater. While urban growth in many PRC 
cities has led to serious air pollution, Hefei has not experienced that. However, further urban 
growth is expected to lead to problems unless they are controlled early. An important part of the 
Project’s urban road infrastructure subcomponent will be traffic management to control congestion, 
accidents, and pollution. 
 
4.  Another major outcome of the Project is flood control. Economic problems from floods have 
always existed, and Hefei has been nearly inundated on several occasions in the past. The city 
has major flood control investments, and the Nanfei is now controlled to a 1-in-100 year flooding 
frequency throughout urban Hefei. The latest step, included in the Project, is to decrease flooding 
to a 1-in-100 year frequency in the three major tributary rivers of the Nanfei, which run into or 
through urban areas, and to between 1-in-20 and 1-in-40 in the parts of more rural Hefei that 
border Chao Lake.  
 
2.  Rationale for Public Intervention 
5.  The serious problems with pollution and flooding demonstrate that private sector responses 
alone  are  inadequate.  Generators  of  wastewater  have  the  incentive  only  to  convey  their 
wastewater far enough downstream to avoid polluting themselves. They do not have any economic 
incentive to treat the wastewater at the point of discharge. Vehicle drivers around the world do not 
realize that the air pollution they cause affects them directly and has a cost to themselves and

Appendix 13       57  
   
others. While the private sector is the victim of flooding, the causes are normally too far away or 
too large for the sector to be able to deal with economically. 
 
6.  The  investment  plan  involves  government  intervention  at  several  different  levels.  The 
central Government has prepared a national level environmental protection plan for Chao Lake. 
The Anhui provincial government has prepared a Chao Lake flood control plan, which has led to 
action by Hefei, one of the two regional level governments that front the lake. Municipal and county 
governments,  particularly  Hefei,  are  making  individual  investments  in  the  flood  control,  river 
cleanup,  and  wastewater  treatment  works.  They  will  be  involved  in  managing  the  completed 
facilities.  
 
7.  Government involvement is sound at each level. Government has a role in controlling 
externalities from discharges of untreated wastewater, coordinating the management of surface 
water quality, and controlling floodwater. Government involvement in individual projects is justified 
since urban flood and water quality control, wastewater management, and urban roads are natural 
monopolies. The local government is adopting various strategies to manage these projects and 
utilities.  Where  output  cannot  be  sold  reasonably,  local  government  departments  will  be  the 
managers and maintainers. Local governments will own revenue-earning utilities, which will be 
managed as independent public enterprises. Contracting out operations and maintenance of the 
wastewater treatment plants (WWTP) to the private sector is encouraged.  
 
2.  Goals of the Investment Plan 
8.  The plan has general and specific goals. The general plans for economic growth and 
development, at the level of Hefei municipal government (HMG), Anhui Province, and PRC as a 
whole,  provide  the  basis  or  context  for  the  goals  specific  to  the  investment  plan.  The  plan 
recognizes  that  achieving  these  goals  will  require  protecting,  improving,  and  maintaining 
environmental quality, particularly surface water and air quality. 
 
9.  The goals most relevant to the investment plan come from the 11th Hefei Environmental 
Plan. Key features are goals for surface water. These are based on five main classifications, set 
according to the intended use of the water. The State Environmental Protection Administration sets 
the  water  quality  goals  for  some  key,  strategic  river  reaches.  More  generally,  the  relevant 
environmental protection department at a county, municipal, or provincial level sets the local water 
quality goal. In Hefei urban areas, the goal is limited only to increasing surface water quality so that 
100% meets Class V. The city’s drinking water does not come from the Nanfei, but upstream from 
the Dafangyin and Dongpu reservoirs. Even those are not yet suitable to be centralized drinking 
water  sources  as  they  can  contain  too  much  nitrogen  and  phosphorous.  The  plan  aims  to 
strengthen source protection to ensure water of at least Class II in the reservoirs. Air quality in 
Hefei is reasonable. Sulfur dioxideand nitrogen dioxideare Class I, while particulate matter (PM ) 
    10
is between Class I and Class II. The plan aims to at least maintain that quality as the city grows.  
 
4.  Design of the Plan 
10.  A unique, least-cost way to achieve all project goals rarely can be found, and any plan that 
satisfies  those  goals  at  minimum  cost  is  acceptable  in  principle.  Standard  economic  theory 
provides  a  least-cost  plan,  based  on  economic  incentives,  for  revenue-earning  activities.  For 
wastewater  management,  this  plan  depends  on  a  centralized  system,  including  sewers  and 
treatment plants. All point-sources should be connected to the sewer system, and the sewers 
should discharge to treatment plants. The Project will be an important source of assistance in 
helping the Hefei plan meet that condition.

11.  The other components of the Project do not earn revenue. In these cases, social choice 
techniques must be used to help design the plan. Such techniques include benefit-cost analysis, 
the  results  of  which  are  discussed  in  Section  C.3.  Another  important  element  promotes  the 
importance  of  projects  that  will  assist  the  poor.  Poverty-related  subcomponent  effects  are 
discussed in Appendix 12 and are summarized in Table A13.1.

12.  Other relevant elements of social choice relate to the means to ensure that decisions taken 
have the support of the people in whose name the decisions are made. The project preparatory 
technical assistance household survey asked for opinions on various government services. Highest 
priorities were education and health, followed by wastewater, and flood and storm water control. 
When high as well as highest priority was included, roads and public transport also had more than 
90% support. 
 
C.  Analysis of Individual Subcomponents 
1.  Least-Cost Analysis of Individual Subcomponents 
13.  The least-cost analysis ensures that each subcomponent is designed optimally to meet the 
goals of the Project. The least-cost analysis should cover all feasible alternatives for a given 
subcomponent, including variations in location, timing, technology, and content. Ideally, least-cost 
analysis also would cover the planning horizon or capacity of the plant, though capacity often is 
constrained by other factors.  
 
14.  In summary, the only real questions that remain relate to the timing of demand for (i) the 
Wangtang II WWTP, (ii) some of the recreational facilities included in the integrated river treatment 
subcomponents, and (iii) the northern part of the Xinzhan Zone road subcomponent. These are all 
demand-related questions and are discussed in Section C.2. Otherwise, the results of the analysis 
confirm that the preferred options given for the subcomponents are least-cost.

Appendix 13       59  
   
2.   Demand for Subcomponents 
15.  The  subcomponents  whose  output  will  be  sold  are  in  the  wastewater  sector,  the  two 
WWTPs,  and  the  sewerage  network.  Following  past  practice  in  Hefei,  revenues  for  these 
components will be determined by costs, and will be paid from wastewater tariffs collected from all 
piped water consumers as part of their water tariff bill. Demand for the subcomponents will depend 
on wastewater output in their supply areas, as well as the ability of the collection system to move 
that wastewater to the WWTP. In the case of the Shiwuli WWTP, forecast output is more than five 
times treatment capacity. As such, full usage of the plant should pose no difficulties, even if it is 
extended to the full 100,000 cubic meter per day (m3/day) capacity. For Wangtang (I and II), 
however, forecast capacity is about equal to forecast wastewater output. Collecting all this output 
will be difficult, and it is uncertain that the budget for the collection system is sufficient. In addition, 
the wastewater forecasts rely on new and planned developments in several areas. While these 
developments are included in the 11th Hefei Environmental Plan, that plan was drafted before 
recent changes in national policy were introduced. These changes will (i) move national emphasis 
from urban back to a more balanced urban and rural policy, (ii) instruct local planners to restrain 
growth if that is necessary to sustain the environment, and (iii) evaluate them accordingly. These 
evaluations are important. Taken together, the changes raise some doubt about the need for the 
capacity planned immediately for the Wangtang II WWTP. One possibility would be to keep in the 
loan sufficient funds for an additional 100,000 m3/day of treatment plant capacity, as requested by 
the Government. However, this could be split into in 50,000 m3/day segments. Decisions could be 
made later in the Project on the needs to expand Shiwuli or Wangtang II WWTPs to include the 
second 50,000 m3/day. 
 
16.  The river cleanup subcomponents contain large sums for amenities. These are in line with 
the past policy of HMG to provide extensive green areas. While the basic ideas are good, the plans 
might be too elaborate. Thus, HMG might wish to review the design and early implementation of 
these expenditures. 
 
17.  The only other subcomponent for which demand will be relevant is the Xinzhan Zone road 
infrastructure. The city is expanding and the location of the local railway system means that the 
Xinzhan Zone area, which is adjacent to the railway station is an obvious place to direct that 
growth. Roads are needed to develop an area. In view of recent changes in national policy, the 
future growth of all PRC cities must raise some doubts. These might be reasons to slow the 
implementation of the more northerly parts of the zone until demand in the south is verified. 
 
3.  Assessment of Individual Subcomponents 
18.  In addition to being least-cost, each subcomponent should be economically justified. The 
first standard for judging a subcomponent is with respect to the project goals. Any subcomponent 
that is least-cost and is identified as an integral component of the Project might be considered 
justified. All subcomponents are integral to the Project. Applying standard benefit-cost analysis can 
strengthen the economic justification of individual subcomponents. This confirmation is useful since 
it allows the main economic parameters to be derived for the individual subcomponents.  
 
19.  The types of benefits of different social service subcomponents vary. They can be difficult 
to quantify, and ensuring no double counting within and across benefits also can be difficult. These 
difficulties  can  be  minimized  through  estimates  for  likely  land  value  increases  since  all 
subcomponents will contribute to the urban development of Hefei. The total affected area, 101 
square kilometers, is 17% of the area of Hefei urban districts, which is another indication of the 
importance of the Project. The areas affected by individual subcomponents do not overlap and the

60  Appendix 13 
“with project” and “without project” land values used were backed by auction data. Benefits were 
assumed to grow over a lengthy delay period. Assumed increases also were compared with the 
increases required to give an EIRR of 12%. In the case of Chao Lake, land value benefits are 
significant (58% of benefits) but are not sufficient. They have been supplemented by shore erosion 
(32%), amenity (7%), and net tourist income (3%) benefits.  
 
20.  The  EIRRs  for  the  representative  subcomponents  range  from  21%  to  36%  for  the 
wastewater management projects, and from 13% to 33% for the other subcomponents. Overall, the 
EIRR is about 27%. The results and assumptions for subcomponents are in Table A13.2. While the 
land  value  increases  assumed  might  seem  high,  experience  elsewhere  has  shown  that  the 
difference between the values of land liable and not liable to flooding can be a factor of four. On 
average, 10 years delay in reaching the estimated increase is assumed. The average increase 
required to produce an EIRR of 12% is 22%. 
 
21.  Details of the sensitivity analysis (Supplementary Appendix L) indicate that the results are 
robust. Only the Qingxi landfill and Chao Lake have EIRRs below 12% when all benefits are 
delayed for the full period shown. The proposed investments are considered economically sound 
and justified.
